item.title: Notes on Microeconomics
item.description: Preference Textbook 1: Rubinstein’s Lecture Notes in Microeconomic Theory (2ed) Textbook 2: Preference Preferences on a set \(X\) are a function \(f\) that assigns to any pair \((x, y)\in X\) exactly one of the three “values” \(x \succ y\), \(y \succ x\), or \(I\) s.t. No order effect: \(f(x,y)=f(y,x)\) Transitivity: if \(f(x,y) = x \succ y\) and \(f(y,z) = y \succ z\), then \(f(x,z) = x \succ z\) Preferences on a set \(X\) is a binary relation \(\succsim\) s.
